newsitem.title: FRANCE: Maastricht less rigid than generally said -Dehaene.
newsitem.headline: Maastricht less rigid than generally said -Dehaene.

text.p: Belgian Prime Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene said in an interview published in Les Echos on Tuesday that the timing and criteria for European monetary union should be adhered to.
But he added the treaty text was less rigid than often said.
"The treaty foresees a date and criteria. They should be kept to and the treaty read as it is: the text is a little less rigid than is often said," Dehaene told the business daily.
"As soon as you start to call the (launch) date into question, you run the risk of having no date at all," he said, adding that putting the euro currency launch date in doubt could "cost us dearly".

He said that Belgium's debt as a proportion of GDP had come down 10 percent in three years and that even if it was not in line with the 60 percent/GDP goal of the Maastricht treaty, the trend was in the right direction.
